Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar's decision to refuse Marcas's trademark application due to insufficient use of the design mark was reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Only three transactions over nearly five years; no sales after 1999; Marcas admitted halting CASTILLO rum sales in Canada in 1999
Burden_of_Proof: On Marcas to demonstrate continuous use of the trademark
Credibility_Factor: Marcas admitted to halting sales, undermining claim of continuous use
Legal_Rule: Under subsection 30(b) of the Trade-marks Act, a trademark must be continuously used in the normal course of trade
Procedural_Issue: Appeal of Registrar's decision on trademark refusal
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient use of the design mark in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Registrar's decision found reasonable; application dismissed
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Registrar conducted proper review based on evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transaction records, admission by Marcas regarding cessation of sales
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law under the Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Marcas challenged the refusal of its trademark application
Defendant_Response: Bacardi opposed the application on grounds of non-use
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; trademark registration refused
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative review followed by judicial review
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of continuous use in normal course of trade
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition and judicial review process
Governing_Rule: Requirement of continuous use under subsection 30(b)
